name: Mugshots Coffeehouse & Cafe

attributes.Ambience: {'romantic': False, 'intimate': False, 'touristy': False, 'hipster': True, 'divey': False, 'classy': False, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': False, 'casual': False}

categories: Vegetarian, Food, Coffee & Tea, Vegan, Sandwiches, Restaurants
llm_reasoning: 85% - The reviews consistently reference coffee items and cafe atmosphere, with 168 of 211 reviews containing category-related keywords.

text:
Yes, it's always crowded, yes, it's expensive, yes, sometimes they will forget that you ordered a coffee and you'll have to remind them, yes, you might get hit up to donate to various political organizations when entering. 

The fact remains, though, that Mugshots has pretty damn tasty coffee and some delicious sandwiches. The Scapegoat is great: soft, cool goat cheese on a hot pressed ciabatta loaf, with pesto, the best red onions I've had in a while, spinach, and tomatoes. Simply, satisfying, and (I will kid myself probably) not too bad for you. Their bagels are also some of the better ones I have been able to find in the city, not too dense, toasted nicely, with flavorful toppings--and the veggie and chive cream cheese are standouts.

As for their hot drinks, they're good, very good. During the winter months I can only come to Mugshots a few times every month because otherwise I would just be ordering the creme brulee latte all of the time, and neither my waistline nor my wallet would thank me. It's a sweet, guilty pleasure. The aztec hot chocolate is also great. 

In addition, although I've never participated in the buying club, I like that Mugshots has the option to buy locally sourced ingredients, although it's probably just cheaper to go to a farmer's market. Still, the homemade red potato salad that they have using these ingredients was a standout that I am going to have to buy again: tangy (it tasted like it had some yogurt in addition to/instead of mayo), chilled, fresh, and bursting with dill and some garlic, it was the perfect accompaniment to our homemade Scapegoat knockoff.

In short, it's pricey, but once in a while, it's nice to drop by, have a drink, and split a tasty, freshly prepared sandwich--just not if you're in a hurry.

Mugshots is one of those places that is awesome on paper, but somehow they manage to fall short in the execution.  Great location..check.  Cool, casual atmosphere...check.  Inked and pierced hipster baristas...check.  Good coffee (the Guatemalen blend is my favorite)...check.

What Mugshots lacks is a good system of service that allows customers to order and receive their drinks and food in a reasonable amount of time without wanting to take hostages.  With their much-anticipated expansion about 2 years back (they doubled their size by taking over the space next door) you'd have thought they would have a better flow going with their drink and food preparation.  Not so much.  Food orders (especially on the weekend when it's most crowded with yuppie weekend warriors and their offspring in strollers) take...roughly..forever!  The staff is mostly friendly, but sometimes seem distracted or disorganized.  The place is not what you'd call a model of efficiency, shall we say.  

OK, maybe I'm being a bit harsh.  But that's because I used to love this place.  I was happy to have a cool, comfortable place in the neighborhood to work on my laptop while sipping on a latte.  Now, they've sealed up most of the power outlets to keep customers from camping out too long (probably a good business decision, but annoying nonetheless), and you have to make a purchase every hour in order to get a unique wi-fi "code" to use their network.  Again, probably good for profits, but do I need to keep having the network drop while I'm working or sending an email?  What Mugshots fails to get is that people WILL spend money if they hang out for a couple of hours, without all the restraints and rules.  Those tend to fly in the face of the laid-back, bohemian vibe they've got going on.

Still...good sandwiches, salads, coffee, and tea.  Plus they're fair-trade and organic, which I kind of like.  

Wish I could do better than a 3, but they're not really there..sorry.

My thoughts on the place are really a mixed bag, but I appreciate their dedication to fair-trade coffees and teas and local ingredients for food, so that bumps them up a star.

I went in here on a Saturday at maybe around 1, and it was ridiculously crowded. I had some time to kill before catching my bus, so I didn't really mind standing in line for a while and browsing their menu. Looks like they have some tasty options, and as someone looking to incorporate more vegan and local cuisine into my diet, I found the menu exciting.  However, the prices on some of these things (and the fact that I was on my way to a Honey's Brunch-- seriously, an addiction) deterred me.  

As a company that snubs Starbucks (and hey, I do too, so I appreciate it!), I was a little perplexed by their coffee menu, which looked like it had some pretty frou-frou and expensive drinks not unlike the bigger chains.  I like places that list a cup of coffee as being COFFEE, not Americano, or "mugshot," whatever that is (is it their coffee? plain? Suppose I could've asked).  I got the Mayan Chai tea, mainly because I found their coffees overpriced.  Let me say, it was delicious!  And I'm really happy they offer a variety of milks (including soy) by the counter, not just cream.  Probably my biggest peeve about DD is that they don't have milks and sugars out on a counter for you to mix in, but my problems with Dunks' should probably be reserved for a different review.

Overall, cute little place, a little overcrowded and hipstery/yuppie-ish, but I like their mission to provide decent vegetarian/vegan options and fair-trade drinks.

COMMENCE RANT:

Terrible, terrible, TERRIBLE customer service. 

My girlfriend and I went to Mugshots yesterday. The place was very crowded, and when it was our turn to order we noticed that there weren't any free seats. So my girlfriend told the cashier that we weren't sure if we were going to order because of the lack of available seating. Before she even finished this sentence, the cashier smirked, pointed to the line like we didn't know it was there, and gestured to the person behind us to place their order. She didn't say a single word to us. 

I understand that that isn't the type of thing a cashier wants to hear when it is busy. We were, however, going to ask her for just a second to decide what we wanted to do. But apparently she didn't feel like giving us the chance. It's like she felt that she was doing us a favor by giving us the opportunity to order, and since we had inconvenienced her so terribly she decided to revoke that privilege. Overall, this woman came off as impatient and condescending. I must say it is ironic for a cashier to have a superiority complex. 

The very fact that there was no available seating was also, in itself, annoying. Normally this wouldn't bother me, but I looked around a bit and noticed that about half of the customers were sitting there typing away on their Macbooks while nursing small coffees (some of them were just drinking water from Nalgene bottles). Even worse, many of them were sitting alone at tables meant for multiple people. And worst of all, every single one of them was a hipster. 

I know I am going to tick a lot of people off with these comments, but let's be serious here: Mugshots isn't just a "coffee shop" like Starbucks. They also serve breakfast and lunch. And people would like the opportunity to sit down and eat said foodstuffs. But they don't get the chance if everyone else thinks its acceptable to buy a cup of coffee and then sit there for extended periods of time writing term papers, brooding poetry, or whatever they consider to be trendy. This is fine when the place isn't so busy, but during rush hours it is downright inconsiderate. THERE IS A REASON WHY THEY PUT A ONE HOUR LIMIT ON WIFI ACCESS FOR CUSTOMERS!!!!!

I should mention that although we left without ordering, we had been to Mugshots once before and the food was pretty tasty. This doesn't make up for the awful customer service and the droves of self-absorbed "cool kid" customers, however. 

So in sum, go to Mugshots if you enjoy:
-Good sandwiches (if you don't mind paying high prices and waiting a half an hour for your food to come out)
-Snarky and disrespectful staff members
-Not being able to find an open seat
-Being around gaggles of hipsters who think the place is a library, or a Starbucks, or something. 

END RANT!

Hubby and I went there on our 1st anniversary since we did not freeze our wedding cake.  We thought that we'd get one fresh instead.

It turns out that they were closing early for a staff meeting so we ended up eating our special piece of cake in the car.  I've tried this cake before and was not even sure if it was the same kind.  I'm wondering if they had a refrigerator issue as the consistency didn't seem right.

The cashier made it seem like he was doing us some kind of favor when we asked for plastic forks with our to-go container.

I've only been there a few times and there was another time that they closed early because they were 'slow'.  I've worked in restaurants before and there is plenty to do behind the counter if there aren't many customers.  Closing early was a huge inconvenience for me because I was supposed to meet with a friend at 9:15 on a Friday night (when it says on their site that they close at 10 PM).  I didn't know where else to go near there where we could chat over coffee.  

Unfortunately for such a mediocre place, they do pretty well because there is little to no competition in the area.  So, I suppose that they can afford a negative review, stale cake and rude staff.

Mugshots and I had a falling out. Oh Mugshots, I used to love you so. Until I branched out and saw that there are other fish (er, coffee shops) in the pond (um, city). 

Positives: The food is great. Organic, fresh ingredients, and I love the vibe there. The staff is pretty nice. Smoothies are good. Coffee is good. I do like their loyalty cards that earn you a free coffee once every 10(?) coffee drinks. 

Negatives: If you sit for an hour (that's all the time you're allotted for internet), you go home smelling like stale coffee. My boyfriend calls it the "Mugshots Smell." The food takes awhile, so don't expect to pop in for a quick bite. There aren't many outlets, so you either get a cold seat by the windows or hog a whole table to yourself.

It's extremely pretentious to restrict internet in an area like Fairmount where there are many people who would love to hang out in a coffee shop and do work. And the fact that it's the biggest establishment in the area means it would probably run a similar one out of business. But please, future coffee shop owners, try! We need a better alternative.

*Note: Rybread on Fairmount is awesome but oh-so small!

I met some friends for lunch here one day because they live in the neighborhood and go to Mugshots all of the time.  I have to say, I really liked this place, so I'll be going back even though I don't live down there.  The atmosphere was really friendly, comfortable, and just hippy/crunchy enough for me because I miss all of the hippies/crunchy people I went to college with.  I think that this would be a place that I'd hang out in all the time if I lived nearby.  It's great for studying or reading or hanging with friends.

The coffee was fantastic, and I got a really good sandwich - the "Capone" wrap, which has free-range smoked turkey, bacon, avocado, lettuce, and tomato with chili mayo and a side of mixed greens.  My friends' lunches all looked really good, too.  I was really surprised and pleased by the variety of vegetarian options on their menu because, even though I'm not a vegetarian, I really like vegetarian food.  I noticed that they have peanut butter and banana sandwiches, too.  How great is that?  This place has a real comfort-food sort of vibe (if you're from, say, Vermont), and I really enjoyed it.  

They also have a location in Manayunk.

Dropped by again this past Saturday (11/29). The sun was out but the wind chill prevailed, and being outdoors while exploring the penitentiary made a hot beverage necessary. You can be damn sure that I kept my ears wide open when I walked in again. I wish I knew the song but all I know for certain that it wasn't Ludacris' "Move, bitch". But jokes aside, the music didn't reaaallly bother me at either time I visited Mugshots.

About the beverage...I ordered an Aztec. I'm no hot chocolate expert so I trusted the server when she dusted cheyenne pepper on the surface, but I didn't pay attention to how much she put in. The first sip was great. It immediately warmed me up, but quite honestly a hot cup of anything would've done the job. My taste buds came back to life as I slowly thawed, but they didn't giving me any good feedback. I barely tasted chocolate and the cheyenne pepper was way too over-powering and my sister, who LOVES anything chocolate, took just one sip and never asked for another.

The interior decor was exactly how I remembered it but unfortunately, my update to my review of Mugshots has changed for the worse.

About 2 years ago, I had an issue with the counter person when I ordered my drink.  The total was $4 and change. When I pulled out my debit card, she told me there was a $10 minimum.  I replied that I didn't have cash and besides my understanding was if you accept a card you cannot set a minimum.  She took the card after she told me that "I said we like a $10 minimum".  OK whatever.  I started going across the street to London's.  My partner and I were in the neighborhood and London's was closed, so, gulp, back to Mugshots.  There was one person in line ahead of us.  My partner got his coffee immediately.  My three shot espresso took an inordinate amount of time to receive, considering there were at least 5 people behind the counter.  A paper cup, maybe a little larger than a Dixie cup was placed in front of me.  When we asked the barista if this was a triple, she said it was.  I asked if she made them short and she gave me a disguisted look and replied that this is "how we make them". What followed was the most horrid expresso I have ever had.  I used to own a coffeehouse and my partner was a barista at another coffeehouse. We know what a shot of espresso looks like and how it should taste.  What I was given was neither.  Oh, and by the way, because I accepted credit cards, the processing fee is not that great and minimums were specifically prohibited.

As a new Fairmount resident, I have to say that I have only a few months of experience with Mugshots. There are definitely good and bad points to it, and the end result is "hmm".

[FYI my new system goes from "God No!" to "Niceeeeeee"]

I put it in the middle because I really expected great things. I had heard about it from the hipster word of mouth chain before I moved, and when I saw it for the first time I thought I might have found my coffee mecca. Unfortunately, the fact that it just seems like it should be incredible really rebounds on you when you find out it's not. 

The Good:

-Great decor/comfy chairs and couches
- Really amazing location
- Clever name
- Hip(ster) clientele AND yuppie clientele both accommodated
- Delicious Pastries

The Bad:

- Disorganized - The coffee station is down behind the counter at the far end, and I walked around like an idiot (much to the staff's delight) until I figured it out. I seriously saw them laugh when I found it :/
- The staff can be hot and cold. Some are nice enough while others are pretty bitchy/unconcerned with what their doing. Most exasperatingly, one guy there (red curly hair and beard) will have a 10 minute long discussion with me about the prison, and then when I come in the next day and ask for a water cup (after I bought an espresso from him 10 seconds earlier and was drinking it outside!) he tells me it's only for customers. I tell him I was just sitting outside with my espresso and he reluctantly gives me a cup. I walk outside and he walks behind me to check and see if I'm lying... Really? For water? What if I was lying? Who really cares?
- The outside seating could be nicer/more comfortable. 
- Wi-Fi for 1 hour? That gives people the feeling that you're pushing them out. A good coffee shop is welcoming and friendly.

The Ugly

- Really the only decent place to get coffee in Fairmount.

Sadly, this place is broken. The food & coffee was fine but the service is slow & the manager has a huge chip on her shoulder. 

I originally drafted this review while sitting outside of mugshots on marathon day. It was 7:23 am.  According to their website, they open at 7am.  I scoped this place out b/c it opened early & would have left if i had the luxury of time.  According to the manager who was setting up chairs outside when I approached, they open at 7:30. She seemed terribly annoyed that she had to speak to a customer a whole 7 minutes before they opened. There were actually 4 of us, including a dude with a baby in a stroller that she passed twice, locking us out until 7:30ish.  We were all confused about the opening time & her inexplicable rudeness.

The service didn't improve once inside. While the cashier was friendly, the manager was making espresso drinks and it took a good 15 min. to get my decaf latte. It took 2 attempts.  She first made a regular & when double checked, she looked at me like I was trying to screw with her.  Then, after checking the order slip, she wordlessly remade it without a word.  And *she's* in charge here. 

I don't know if they were busier than normal this morning b/c of the marathon or if they are always slow but the people around me were complaining about how long it took to get their food. And on top of it, for some reason they couldnt take credit cards. 

 It seems that this place needs a bit of an overhaul in general, but the big problem seems to be management. 

 If Iived here, I wouldn't be back. The coffee was good, I have to admit. But here's the thing: it's about the way you treat people. It's about how welcome your customers feel. You don't have to kiss ass, but the idea is that your customers keep the joint open. Be nice to them. It's not that hard. A little kindness goes a long way.

First of all, let's all welcome me to the Fairmount Neighborhood! Yes, I finally moved... But that's enough about me, let's talk coffee. Now, as some of you know, I am a huge fan of "La Colombe" and I rarely cheat on it but "Mugshots" is so close by that it's just that much easier to go there when I am at home, or when I am walking to work (30 minute is much less painful with a cap of java)...  

Now, there is a reason why I mentioned the 30-minute walk and that reason is: I work in center city, the cafe is really NOT in center city, and the prices don't even come close to what they should be. I mean,  I pay $2.75 for a "La Colombe" latte (Rittenhouse Sq.) and I paid at least a $1 more for the same size latte at "Mugshots". Seriously? I mean, I get that the place is hipster-cool and, as seen by the lines and the lack of available tables, popular but it doesn't mean that the prices have to be so disproportionate. 

Overall:
1. Ambiance is very hipster-cool (interior design and the patrons)
2. Food is pretty good from what I tried
3. Prices are highly disproportionate to the location
4. Outside seating is lacking... 3 tiny tables, often occupied by people who didn't even get anything at the cafe
5. Coffee could be better but, then again, I am a "La Colombe" snob so I am biased
6. Customer Service seems to have its good days and its bad days, depending on who you get

Due to the convenient location, I am sure I will become a regular regardless of points above but it would be nice if these points are noted

I went here on a Friday at around 4 pm so, unlike other reviewers, I  can't judge the staff's speed efficiency. When I stumbled upon this place we were the first (and only) people in line, there were about 10 people in the place altogether, and our food/coffee was out in a jiffy. Overall, a great customer experience for me. The lady talked to me about what they offered and signed me up for their coffee rewards club (buy 12 - I think - coffees/coffee drinks and get a free one). I was sold. 

I am very impressed by their food menu. I like that you can get soy cream cheese, breakfast bowls with rice, several vegetarian sandwiches, and vegan desserts. We only tried one thing that day - the Vegan Rueben. It was tasty. Rueben's are the thing I miss the most and often dream about finding the perfect Vegan Rueben. Was this it? No. But it was pretty close. 

You know what was beyond amazing? Their Americano. I drink it black, no sugar, and it was perfect. Not too much of anything. Can't wait for another.

On my way out I picked up a flyer about a program they have that I thought was interesting and will try. When I try it I will update. They allow you to order local produce through them and then you pick it up on Friday or Saturday. The produce they get is through the farm that supplies the Cafe so they are just adding on to their order. They do earn some money from this service but I think it is fantastic. I work long hours in Philly and commute back home to Delaware (which means I have little time or energy to frequent farmer's markets). 

Only 4 stars because I went once .... I want to test out the "long lines" and customer service.

Excuse me, I need to rant for a bit:
I think one of the main reasons people have bad experiences here is because they come expecting bad service, or they expect star treatment every time they go in because they feel they are a "regular". One of my favorite pastimes is to stand in line and watch people get angry because they don't get what they want. Pro-tip: you're probably not that special

What people forget when they make a decision to skip Starbucks and hit up a local coffee shop is that they forfeit their rights to "have it your way" service. Small places like this have specific/original menus for reasons. As soon as one starts deviating from it, mistakes are just asking to be made. You're not eating at a Stephen Starr restaurant- you're getting a burrito and a coffee.

Also, tickets get lost, mixed up or even forgotten. I've sat many places and watch the same food I ordered get served out to people who placed their orders after me. It happens

For as much as I'm willing to stick my neck out for Mugshots, I will admit there have been many a times I've walked away unhappy with my order. But that's part of eating out- you're not guaranteed perfection every time. Maybe the kitchen messed up, maybe the produce for the week isn't that good, maybe suppliers have been switched. Who knows, but goodness knows you most likely don't.

The food here is pretty darn good, the coffee has gotten way better and the customer service, although shaky, is great if you can take the time out of your day to treat the person behind the counter like a human being. It may be false that you catch more flies with honey than with vinegar, but you certainly do catch more smiles.

farm fresh hormone free lancaster milk! cage-free vegetarian-fed hens, y'all.  recovery shakes? also tons of vegan and veg options here. 

Unfortunately, we tourists arrived too late for famed brunch, and we thought it was too early for homemade guac, and  endless choices, but "ask and thou shalt receive" and I got the last lancaster bacon and cheese frittata and, though it felt different to have bacon bits in a perfect EGG, it was AMAZING, SEXY light, lovely. And even had to order it with my vegan friends.  

i felt so French with my Frittata, seeking such homeostasis with friends on the cafe couch, looking at art?, talking about traveling, and getting ready to go to yet another museum. 

BEST FRUIT BAR EVER. Homemade Famous Fourth Street bakery raspberry lime bars. Butter, sugar, egg  proportioned like some beautiful woman. They also have packaged vegan bars.  The Champ is  Chocolate soy milk, bananas and organic peanut butter. oh my?! Surprisingly scrumptious. Many dishes are named after prison references, very punny, mugshots has great  FAIR TRADE coffee, of course.

After Mugshots it's across the street to the gothic Eastern State Penitentiary, one of my favorite museums in the world, right up there with Experience Music Project!!

-philly i so have a crush on you with your buying fresh from farms and your otherly urban charms-

I'm unimpressed.

It's expensive. I mean, this isn't right in center city, I think they can push down the prices a smidgen. 

The service is snobby. The people working here make me feel like they are doing ME a favor by taking my order.

The internet is restricted. Not only must you SPECIFICALLY ask for a separate receipt for the wireless code, it's limited to ONE hour use only. Seriously? Why the f would I do that when I could go to basically any other coffee shop in the city for unlimited?  L-A-M-E.

I thought their saving grace would be the cool weekday events they host such as movie nights, open mic night, etc. BUT I tried one of the Monday movie nights and was sorely disappointed. First off, they started the movie WITHOUT bothering to focus the projector or turn the volume to an audible level. When I confronted the the staff about this (I had to...TWICE) it took them a whole 15 MINUTES to do come over and fix it. They told me they were "busy". There were 5 customers in the entire cafe.

So we can finally see and (kind of) hear the movie after missing the first 20 minutes. The rest is fine until it hits 8:30PM and the clean up begins. Translation: clattering of pots and pans, clinking glass and loud banter amongst the staff. We have to strain to hear the rest of the movie - I don't dare ask a third time to turn up the volume for fear of the jarring sneers. 

I understand that the priority here is the café but WHY have a movie showing if you aren't going to take any care to make it a pleasurable viewing experience?

It's disappointing because the food (seitan rice bowl) and drink (toasted almond/vanilla Italian soda) were really good.  I still left with a sour taste in my mouth, however.

My girlfriend and I came here on Labor day of this year both before and after visiting the Eastern State Penitentiary across the street. I was super impressed each time. If this place was in Syracuse, I would frequent it often.

They had a ton of vegan options on the menu (which appealed to us as we are both vegan) and some amazing Vegan Treat desserts. It was mad busy when we went there but we found a table without much trouble. My girlfriend got the Vegan BLT with apple and enjoyed it thoroughly. They use the tempeh bacon which I am generally not a huge fan of, but overall, the sandwich was delicious. She also got the vegan chili and was unable to finish it due to it being way too hot for her... which made it perfect for me!  I got "The Slammer"  which is a wrap with vegan sausage, guacamole, salsa and lettuce. It was a tad small for my liking, but the taste was undeniably good.

The also offer a ton of smoothies, juices and milkshakes all with vegan options. We ended up getting the organic lemonade with blueberries... simple and amazingly delicious.

I also got a cafe au lait with soymilk which was pretty good. I am not a huge coffee afficianado so unless something it really bad, it's pretty much all the same to me.

One of the overriding negative comments on here about this place is the slow service. Like I said earlier, I went there on Labor Day and they were PACKED. It took us about 10 minutes to even order and another 20 for our names to be called for our food... not that bad given how busy it was. Everyone behind the counter seemed to be hustling and doing their best to get the food out as quickly as possible.  Give these guys a break... working in food service is super hard and unless you've been there and done it, you really don't have a clue as to how hard it is to serve a restaurant full of people in a timely manner.

Kudos to you Mugshots.

The next I am in Philly, I will definitely be stopping by!

The taste (or lack thereof) of baked eggs is still lingering on my breath as I write this.

This is a tale of a local coffee shop swallowed into the branding of some corporate big-wigs.

I had been patronizing Mugshots for over a year and have never felt dissatisfaction once, until now.

After switching hands, (management or ownership, it is a bit unclear) Mugshots has officially jumped the shark. What does a girl want more than an egg sandwich on a Saturday morning. Instead of nice eggs, folded over from the griddle, I received some baked holey mess. Instead of cheese spilling over the eggs it was seemingly absent.

When inquiring about the aesthetics and taste of the rubbery eggs the one employee began an obviously rehearsed spiel about how more people prefer their eggs baked and fluffy, that it's healthier and the eggs are so local they were fresh, just delivered yesterday. 

To give credit where credit is due, he did try to accommodate by offering to make the sandwich again, yet it would still be baked into a square chunky mess of holey eggs. I declined and he told me that all major chains like Dunkin Donuts and Wawa bake their eggs, still harping on how most people prefer it that way.

If I was looking for shitty baked eggs I would go to Wawa, pay way less and wouldn't regret trying to get decent food from a presumably locally owned establishment. 

It was at this point that the one line-cook offered to fry me some eggs on the griddle, something that the other employee never even offered. I was grateful that someone was listening to a customer's opinion instead of reciting what popular opinion polls found. 

I understand new owners mean a new style of doings things, but I didn't think when the shop boasted on Facebook about shorter waiting times it meant they were industrializing local and creating a more popular, yet less tasty egg.

I will have to look elsewhere for a morning breakfast sandwich, unfortunately I am of the apparent minority who prefers an old fashioned egg. At the age of 28 I guess you need to get off my lawn.

I've been saying I am going to write a review about this place for quite some time - usually after something so infuriating happens that I leave the shop shaking with anger and my boyfriend and I walk home muttering "never again." However, I am the type that can drop transgressions easily and move on so by the time I take the 4 block trek home, I'm over it enough to not log onto Yelp.

However, today was the last straw. 

The overall reason for a one star review is the total lack of customer service in any capacity whatsoever. I have never once had an experience there related to customer/employee interaction that has EVER been more than a two at most. I'm going to go ahead and share all of these experiences. Maybe (but probably not) someone at Mugshots will care this time. 

Today: Brought all my school work and computers down to Mugshots to work on school work. There Wi-fi is accessible for 60 minutes only with purchase and with a code provided by the cashier (I am not even complaining about this fact but still, come one guys, free wi-fi is a little give for a lot of get in the coffee shop world. Your image could use a boost.). I also ordered an egg, tomato, guacamole, and cheese sandwich and an americano. Americano was fine. Sandwich was made with obviously old guac...it was brown, cold, and flavorless as avocados tend to become when refrigerated for too long. I was contemplating asking for a different sandwich but then I thought better of it because I would just be met with blank stares and don't care attitudes (those things are extremely commonplace with the staff). The first code I received for wi-fi access came up with "promotional access denied." So I asked for assistance, was given another code, and that one did not work either. When I went back to the counter and said that it didn't work either the guy said he didn't know. He asked two of his co-workers about it and they said "Last time it happened, we had to call the company." Then the three of them kinda stood there with blank stares (like I said, a common response). Then the guy said "Well, how do I do that." One girl shrugged her shoulders and the other said "Oh, I don't know I don't go into the office." More blank stares then the guy said to me, "Sorry, I don't know what to do." What?! You DO know what to do, dude. Call the company and fix the problem. Obviously this has happened before as your co-workers pointed out and obviously the solution is to call the provider. However, none of them wanted to do it so I was told "Too bad." Really, Mugshots? You know how to solve a problem but you don't do it because...you're lazy? You don't want to? It's not "your" job? What is it? This is a common theme throughout all of my negative experiences here. Disconnected, disinterested, too-cool-for-school employees who can't be bothered with simple customer service. 

A summary of other complaints:

1. A few weeks ago I ordered an Americano. There were three people at the registers and one person in the kitchen area. I waited 18 minutes (I timed it on my phone) before I said anything. I said "excuse me, is someone going to make my drink?" Yes, I said it with a little bit of an attitude. The girl stared at me (blank stares!) then said, "Yea, give me am minute" and went back to the registers where two other people were (there are only two registers so...) Two minutes later she went to the espresso machine clearly annoyed and sloppily made my drink. It was filled all the way to the top making it difficult to carry to the condiment stand. I felt it was done on purpose. My evidence: the smirk and "here you go" delivered with an attitude when she handed me the drink.

2. Last Saturday morning (an insanely busy time at Mugshots) I was waiting in line along with 16 other customers (I counted because I wanted to write a Yelp review and be accurate) for my morning coffee. Some man walks in the door, cuts to an open register before the woman waiting in line gets to it. The woman seemed confused and said she was too embarrassed to say anything so I leaned over and said to the cashier, "That man just cut in front of everyone." The cashier look flustered, said "oh, I just got here" and continued to help the man instead of asking him to wait in line. Yea, no. 

3. The food and drink are over-priced for the quality of customer service. I understand that Mugshots supports local and sustainable farms and I truly appreciate that and understand that that means higher prices. I wouldn't have a problem paying them if I was treated like the PAYING customer that I am.


So, the reason why I keep going here is two-fold. One, I live 4 blocks away and I will put up with a lot for convenience and non-Starbucks coffee. Two, I'm somehow convinced it will get better. I, for some reason, believe management will catch on to the arrogant, disrespectful ignorant way it's staff operates and make changes. Meh, I'm done Mugshots.

when it comes to unpretentious indie coffeehouses Mugshots is definitely the real deal. It has a chill bunch of coffee baristas dishing out equal exchange coffee, delicious teas, and impressive sounding recovery shakes. It also has killer food with plenty of vegetarian options and a commitment to serving locally grown food that could rival White Dog Cafe.

I went to try it out during the Arts Crawl and while it was big time packed I felt that it was well deserved and decided to wait around with the pack. Glad I did because the Vegan Chaingang was one of the best wraps that I've ever had. with hummus, tomatoes, red onion, peppers, and loads of greens it hit the spot. And the Ice Tea that I picked up was mighty plentiful.

So even if the wait may be awhile definitely give it a shot (can't picture it being as busy as the Art Crawl crowd made it). because in the end you'll get some great food, and you might get a good laugh if it's named after a gangster. definitely take advantage of the comfy couches or outdoor seating too.
